user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CountSemDelete:
```c
int32 OS_CountSemDelete(osal_id_t sem_id)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sem_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_CountSemDelete_Impl(&token);

        /* Complete the operation via the common routine */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(return_code, &token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sem_id, &token);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated in this fragment. The code passes the address of a locally-declared OS_object_token_t to a routine that, in context, is expected to populate/modify that token (i.e. the parameter should be OS_object_token_t *). Rule 8.13 requires pointers be to const-qualified types only when the pointed-to object is not modified. Here the token is intended to be written by OS_ObjectIdGetById, so a non-const pointer is appropriate. (A violation would exist only if OS_ObjectIdGetById does not modify *token but its prototype uses a non-const pointer instead of const OS_object_token_t *.)
